subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Call for QS keyboard proposals, with voting in January
msgSnippet: I came down with a severe case of Pre-Holiday Real Life Chaos yesterday, so things got a bit held up. It also turns out I had turned my original text file into
messageBody:
I came down with a severe case of Pre-Holiday Real Life
Chaos yesterday, so things got a bit held up. It also
turns out I had turned my original text file into a mess
by erroneously saving a HTML version over it, so I had
to re-create it from the HTML -- not *that* hard thanks
to Firefox's save as text feature, but still 1h+ of
extra job...

On 19.12.2007 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> I only have one question. In BP2, did you intend to drop
> 'Up', the alternate for #36? In that position in your
> chart you've listed 'Utter' again.

A pure copy-and-paste error, it turned out. I also had both
columns labeled "BPJ 1" in the TAB file. Yesterday I
uploaded corrected and updated versions -- and double-
checked that I haven't mixed up CSV and TSV/TAB this time...

> Note: I had intended to require the use of upper and lower
> case Roman letters for all 46 QS letters on this
> list. But your proposal arrived before I could try
> to impose that requirement, so you're good.

I was not so good, since I'd assigned Utter to the backtick
in BPJ 2. I've made some adjustments, and hence a revision
to BPJ 2.1 as follows:

### Revision: 20.12.2007
| | | Jerome | BPJ 2 | BPJ 2.1 |
| ---| -----------| -------| ------| --------|
| 36 | Utter | a | ` | u |
| 39 | Foot | U | u | V |
| 36 | Up | u | V | C |
| | naming-dot | / | ^ | ` |
| | half-Ye | ^ | C | ^ |

As you can see I've been influenced by yours and other's
proposals, though I had the thought of mapping Up to _C_,
which looks like Up, before, especially in following the
native speakers'/writers' near unanimous desire to map Utter
to _u_, which is understandable, though spellings like {ubBt
u monjUmunt} worry me a bit.

On 20.12.2007 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> Thanks, Benct. I've just updated the spreadsheet and
> uploaded it. This version contains your changes, Moira's
> proposal, and a few small changes to QS-Nu.
>
> One change I made was to adopt your mapping for #21 and
> the alternate for #23. It's a vast improvement in the
> second case, and only a minor loss (it seems to me) for
> #21. I should have thought of this myself, since 'g' is
> used for /N/ in Fijian (one of the languages I've
> studied).

Yes. Fijian also uses _q_ for /Ng/ IIRC. I once suggested
the use of _g_ for /N/ and _q_ for /g/ in transcribing
Tibetan. Not that it caught on... For some reason I tend to
see word- initial _ng_ as a spelling error even when I know
better, finding myself writing my Tibetan name as _Gnawang_
instead of _Ngawang_ -- and I'm not even particularly fond
of palindromes! :-)

I'll have to adapt QS to Tibetan some day...

> I should have said earlier that in creating a mapping
> proposal, everyone is encouraged to copy one another!

It seems we are already on a convergence course, which is of
course a Good Thing. Since the problematic areas are
emerging (##14 15 16 17 21 alt-23 36 and the 'long' vowels),
while there seems t essentially already be a concensus on
#8, the 'Celtic' letters and the X-s it is good to be able
to discuss them. With a bit of luck we can arrive on a
compromise proposal before voting time!

> Question: is the time frame I've suggested OK with
> everyone? If people would like more time to make
> proposals, we can move the deadline into 2008. December 31
> was a completely arbitrary choice on my part. Would
> sometime in January be better?

I think January 31 would be a good time, since we have the
Holidays coming up. I'll essentially be offline from 24.12-
7.1, for example.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
